questions.text: A patient suffered a motor vehicle accident and developed breathlessness following the accident. Upon obtaining a CXR, it was found that he had developed a pneumothorax, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely cause of developing a pneumothorax?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the history, the most probable pneumothorax is traumatic pneumothorax, so the likely cause is Rib fracture

  • Traumatic pneumothorax refers to pneumothorax caused by chest trauma (penetrating or nonpenetrating, accidental or iatrogenic) or mechanical ventilation. In this case, the rib fracture is the underlying cause.
  • Pneumothorax associated with mechanical ventilation is usually the result of high ventilator pressures; pneumothorax with mechanical ventilation usually occurs because of alveolar rupture, which in turn causes interstitial emphysema, pneumomediastinum, and rupture of the pneumomediastinum into the pleural space.
  • Pneumothorax does not cause pneumomediastinum; it is the other way around.
  • Also, interstitial air may track to a subpleural location, form a subpleural bleb, and rupture directly into the pleural space.
  • Traumatic pneumothorax usually requires chest tube drainage.

Explanation of Other Options:

Rupture of bullae (Option A):

  • Would cause spontaneous pneumothorax, not commonly seen directly after trauma unless pre-existing bullous disease.
  • No history suggests pre-existing lung disease or bullae.

Iatrogenic (Option C):

  • Unlikely in this scenario.
  • No history of a recent procedure.
  • Not common immediately after trauma unless intubation or other procedures were performed.

Spontaneous (Option D):

  • By definition, it occurs in the absence of trauma.
  • Since the patient had an accident, this rules out a spontaneous cause.

Reference: Thoracic Imaging: Pulmonary and Cardiovascular Radiology, Edition-3, page Number: 2134

choices.text: Doing a CECT of the abdomen

questions.text: A patient received a blunt injury to the abdomen. Following the injury, the patient was rushed to the emergency department. He was hemodynamically stable and underwent a FAST examination. In the FAST examination, moderate hemoperitoneum was found. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In hemodynamically stable patients, the next best step after a positive FAST is a contrast-enhanced CT (CECT can of the abdomen.

CECT provides detailed information on:

  • Organ lacerations (e.g., liver, spleen, kidney)
  • Active bleeding (contrast extravasation)
  • Retroperitoneal injuries
  • Amount and distribution of hemoperitoneum

Helps determine whether the patient can be managed conservatively or needs surgical or interventional radiologic management.

FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma)

It is a bedside ultrasound-based tool used in trauma patients to detect internal bleeding (particularly free fluid). It's quick, non-invasive, and repeatable, making it ideal for emergency settings.

FAST Exam Views Include:

  1. Pericardial view (subxiphoid): For pericardial effusion/tamponade
  2. Right upper quadrant (Morison's pouch): Liver-kidney interface
  3. Left upper quadrant: Spleen-kidney interface
  4. Pelvic view: Bladder and pouch of Douglas
  5. (Extended FAST - eFAST)Includes lung views to detect pneumothorax/hemothorax

Explanation of Other Options:

Doing a repeat FAST (Option A): Repeat FAST is useful if the initial FAST is equivocal or negative, but clinical suspicion remains high.

Observing the patient and follow-up (Option C): Observation without further imaging is not appropriate when moderate hemoperitoneum is already detected. Even if the patient is stable, observation alone would delay definitive diagnosis and appropriate intervention.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department following an RTA. What is the most likely type of fracture seen in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the X-ray, the most probable type of fracture would be Comminuted

  • Comminuted fractures are fractures where more than 2 bone components are created.
  • The problem with the term is that it encompasses a very heterogeneous group of fractures, ranging from a 3-part humeral head fracture to a multi-part fracture of the femur following a high-energy road traffic accident.

Radiological Appearance:

  • Multiple fragments at the fracture site.
  • Irregular, shattered appearance.
  • Often associated with soft tissue damage.

choices.text: Fracture line which crosses the carotid canal

questions.text: Which of the following injuries requires evaluation by angiography?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A fracture involving the carotid canal raises concern for injury to the internal carotid artery (ICA), which runs through this canal.
  • Such fractures can lead to complications like arterial dissection, pseudoaneurysm, or even complete transection, posing a risk for ischemic stroke or hemorrhage.
  • Therefore, angiographic evaluation via CT angiography (CTA) or digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is recommended to assess for vascular injury.

Cranio cervical CTA should also specifically be considered

  1. in the setting of penetrating neck injury,
  2. if a fractured foramen transversarium or facet subluxation is identified on cervical spine CT, or
  3. if a skull base fracture traverses the carotid canal or a dural venous sinus. Arterial laceration or dissection, traumatic pseudoaneurysm, carotid-cavernous fistula, or dural venous sinus injury are nicely depicted on high-resolution CTA.

Explanation of Other Options:

Middle ear injury (Option A):

Middle ear injuries may result from temporal bone fractures, but angiography is generally not required unless:

  • There's vascular bleeding from nearby vessels (e.g., sigmoid sinus, ICA) - rare.
  • Hearing loss and CSF otorrhea are more common concerns.
  • Diagnosis is typically made via high-resolution CT (HRCT) of the temporal bone.

Le Fort fracture (Option C):

  • Le Fort fractures involve the midface (maxillary) but do not routinely require angiography unless there is:
    • Massive facial bleeding.
    • Suspicion of injury to the internal maxillary artery or branches of the external carotid artery.
  • Most Le Fort injuries are evaluated by CT of facial bones; angiography is reserved for active bleeding or when embolization is planned.

Epidural Hematoma (EDH) (Option D):

  • EDH is most commonly due to laceration of the middle meningeal artery.
  • Diagnosed by non-contrast CT head.
  • Surgical evacuation is the treatment of choice.
  • Angiography is not routinely indicated unless there are:
    • Recurrent hemorrhage
    • Suspected vascular anomaly

questions.text: A 32-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. He was initially conscious but became unresponsive 1 hour later. A non-contrast CT head is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical scenario and the CT, the most probable diagnosis would be an Epidural hemorrhage

Explanation of Other Options:

Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage (IPH) ( Option C)

  • Bleeding within the brain parenchyma itself.
  • Causes: hypertension, trauma, AV malformations, tumors, or coagulopathy.

CT Features:

  • Hyperdense area within brain tissue (basal ganglia, thalamus, lobar regions).
  • Surrounded by edema.
  • May extend into the ventricles (intraventricular hemorrhage).

Clinical Clue:

  • Sudden onset of focal neurological deficits or coma.

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH) ( Option D)

  • Bleeding into the subarachnoid space, between the arachnoid and pia mater.
  • Often caused by a ruptured berry aneurysm or trauma.

CT Features:

  • Hyperdensity in basal cisterns, sulci, or interhemispheric fissures.
  • May extend into the ventricles.

Clinical Clue:

  • Sudden, severe "thunderclap" headache, ± neck stiffness,s or loss of consciousness.

questions.text: Which of the following devices is most likely shown on the X-ray?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The device shown on the X-ray is an Intra-aortic balloon pump

  • Intra-aortic balloon pumps (IABP) are used in the intensive care setting to provide hemodynamic assistance to patients in cardiogenic shock. The device is comprised of a catheter introduced via a femoral artery sheath, which extends retrogradely to the proximal descending thoracic aorta.
  • This has a dual effect: it firstly decreases left ventricular afterload through a vacuum effect, decreasing myocardial oxygen requirements, and secondly increases myocardial perfusion (during diastole).
  • On a chest radiograph, it should be at the level of the AP window. This ideally results in the balloon terminating just above the splanchnic vessels

Explanation of Other Options:

ICD (Intercostal Drain) tube (Option B):

  • A chest tube was placed into the pleural space via an intercostal approach.
  • Used to drain air (pneumothorax), fluid (effusion), or blood (hemothorax).

CXR Appearance:

  • Radiopaque line entering laterally through the chest wall.
  • Tip typically located in pleural space, often directed toward apex (air) or base (fluid).

Umbilical Artery Catheter (UAC) (Option C)

  • A vascular catheter is placed via the umbilical artery in neonates.
  • Used for arterial blood sampling and blood pressure monitoring.

Radiographic Appearance:

  • Inserted through the umbilicus.
  • Courses into descending aorta (via internal iliac artery), either:
    • High position: T6-T9
    • Low position: L3-L5

Reference:

Gaillard, F., Weerakkody, Y. Intra-aortic balloon pump. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org. https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-22403

questions.text: A motor vehicle accident patient suddenly developed hypotension. On ECHO screening, the following image was obtained. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A patient with blunt chest trauma who develops sudden hypotension and whose echocardiogram shows a large pericardial effusion with diastolic chamber collapse is classic for Cardiac tamponade
  • Cardiac tamponade is the result of an accumulation of fluid, pus, blood, gas, or benign or malignant neoplastic tissue within the pericardial cavity, which can occur either rapidly or gradually over time, but eventually, results in impaired cardiac output.

Clinical triad (Beck's triad):

  • Hypotension
  • Muffled heart sounds
  • Jugular venous distension
  • This is to be distinguished from a pericardial effusion, which can be very large but does not necessarily impair cardiac function. Chest radiographs may show cardiomegaly with or without an epicardial fat pad sign suggesting a pericardial effusion
  • Echocardiography is considered the gold standard, and commonly first line, imaging modality for assessment of cardiac tamponade. This is due to its ability to provide detailed structural and functional information about the heart, pericardium, and inferior vena cava (IVC). It also allows approach planning for pericardiocentesis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Pericardial Rupture (Option A):

  • Rare and often fatal unless tamponade or cardiac herniation occurs.
  • This can lead to sudden decompression of the tamponade (transient improvement).
  • May present with:
    • Absent heart border on X-ray
    • Cardiac herniation

Cardiac Failure (Option C):

  • Refers to impaired myocardial contractility.
  • May occur chronically or acutely (e.g., post-MI).
  • ECHO findings:
    • Global or segmental wall motion abnormalities
    • Dilated chambers
    • Reduced ejection fraction

Myocardial Infarction (MI) (Option D):

  • Rare in trauma, more often occurs due to coronary artery disease.
  • ECHO findings:
    • Regional wall motion abnormality
    • No pericardial effusion

Reference: Radswiki, T., Sharma, R. Cardiac tamponade. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org.

https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-12376

questions.text: A 27-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He is hemodynamically stable but reports left upper quadrant abdominal pain and left shoulder tip pain. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the CT image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the CT shown, the most probable diagnosis is a Splenic laceration. CT shows Linear or irregular hypodense areas within the splenic parenchyma. Splenic trauma can occur after blunt or penetrating trauma or secondary to medical intervention (i.e., iatrogenic).

Clinical features:

  • Kehr's sign (referred pain to the left shoulder due to diaphragmatic irritation)
  • Left upper quadrant pain
  • The spleen is the most frequently injured internal organ after blunt trauma Splenic parenchyma should be assessed in the portal venous phase, as the inhomogeneous splenic enhancement (zebra or psychedelic spleen) seen on the arterial phase can mimic splenic laceration/contusion; arterial phase scanning can be useful in detecting vascular injuries such as pseudoaneurysm and AV fistula
  • Lacerations appear as linear or branching hypodensities (geographic pattern)

Explanation of Other Options:

Liver Laceration ( Option A):

  • Also seen in blunt trauma, but affects the right upper quadrant.
  • CT would show hypodense linear defects in the liver, possibly with perihepatic fluid.

Pancreatic Injury ( Option C)

  • Rare and harder to detect on initial imaging.
  • CT may show:
    • Ill-defined hypodensity in the pancreas
    • Peripancreatic fluid or stranding
    • Delayed findings can include pancreatic duct injury or pseudocyst formation.
  • More central pain (epigastric)

Rib Fracture ( Option D)

  • Common with blunt trauma.
  • CT or X-ray shows disruption in the cortical continuity of ribs.
  • May cause underlying splenic or pulmonary injury, but not a solid organ laceration.

Reference: Knipe, H., Botz, B. Splenic trauma. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a motorcycle accident. He sustained a straddle injury on the fuel tank and is now unable to pass urine. A retrograde urethrogram is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The retrograde urethrography shows extravasation of contrast outside the urethral lumen without filling the bladder, which implies the most probable diagnosis would be Urethral trauma.

Urethral Injuries

  • More common in males than females.
  • Classic signs: blood at meatus, inability to void, perineal ecchymosis, but not always reliable.
  • Digital rectal exam may reveal blood in some cases.
  • Imaging:
    • Posterior urethra: Evaluate with voiding cystourethrography.
    • Anterior urethra: Evaluate with retrograde urethrography.
  • Retrograde urethrogram shows contrast extravasation at injury site.
  • Important to determine if injury is above (anterior) or below (posterior) the urogenital diaphragm.
  • Incomplete injuries may lead to strictures.

Explanation of Other Options:

Option:

  • Occurs from pelvic fractures or blunt trauma to the lower abdomen.
  • Diagnosed with CT cystography, not RUG.
  • Two types:
    • Intraperitoneal rupture - contrast outlines bowel loops.
    • Extraperitoneal rupture - contrast tracks around the bladder, along fascial planes.

Ureteral Trauma (Option C):

  • Rare, usually iatrogenic (e.g. during surgery).
  • Diagnosed with delayed-phase contrast CT (urogram phase) or retrograde pyelography.
  • CT findings:
    • Delayed contrast excretion
    • Contrast extravasation
    • Ureteral discontinuity

questions.text: A patient with a history of facial trauma sustained multiple fractures. Six months later, he developed a clear, watery nasal discharge that tested positive for beta-2 transferrin. The following structure must have been damaged in the patient. What is it known as?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical scenario, the most probable diagnosis would be CSF rhinorrhea, and the structure shown in the CT is a Cribriform plate

  • The cribriform plate (less commonly also called the lamina cribrosa of the ethmoid bone) is a sieve-like structure between the anterior cranial fossa and the nasal cavity.
  • It is a part of the ethmoid bone and supports the olfactory bulb, which lies in the olfactory fossa. It is perforated by foramina for the passage of the olfactory nerves and the anterior ethmoidal nerves to the upper part of the nasal septum, the latter of those to the superior nasal concha.
  • The lateral lamella forms the lateral border of the plate.

Fractures here can lead to:

  • CSF rhinorrhea
  • Meningitis risk
  • Anosmia (loss of smell)

Explanation of Other Options:

Nasal Turbinate (Option A): The nasal turbinates are bony structures within the nasal cavity, and while trauma can cause bleeding or obstruction, they are not part of the cranial base and do not cause CSF leaks.

Ethmoidal Sinus (Option B): Ethmoidal sinuses lie within the ethmoid bone, and although fractures may lead to orbital emphysema or sinusitis, they are not typically a direct source of CSF rhinorrhea unless the cribriform plate is involved.

Lamina Papyracea (Option D): The lamina papyracea forms the medial orbital wall and, though easily fractured, causes orbital complications rather than CSF leakage and is not part of the anterior cranial base.

questions.text: What is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The CT image shows orbital fat or muscle herniating into the maxillary sinus - classic "teardrop" appearance.

Teardrop sign:

  • Seen in: Blow-out fracture of the orbital floor (inferior wall).
  • Mechanism: Blunt trauma increases intraorbital pressure, fracturing the thin orbital floor and allowing herniation of orbital fat and/or inferior rectus muscle into the maxillary sinus.
  • Imaging: CT (especially coronal) shows a soft tissue density protruding from the orbit into the maxillary sinus - shaped like a teardrop.
  • Clinical signs:
    • Diplopia (especially on upward gaze)
    • Infraorbital numbness (due to infraorbital nerve injury)
    • Periorbital swelling/ecchymosis

Explanation of Other Options:

Supraorbital Rim Fracture (Option A):

  • Involves: Upper margin of the orbit, part of the frontal bone.
  • Seen in: High-impact trauma (e.g., frontal bone fractures).
  • Imaging: Discontinuity or step-off in the superior orbital rim.

Medial Wall of Orbit Fracture ( Option B):

  • Involves the lamina papyracea (part of the ethmoid bone).
  • May cause: Orbital emphysema if ethmoid air cells are breached.

Bow Tie Sign ( Option D):

  • Completely unrelated to orbit.
  • Seen in thoracic spine imaging, specifically:
    • Unilateral facet dislocation
    • Appears on axial CT as misaligned facets forming a "bow tie" shape

Reference: Bickle, I., Evangelou, K. Teardrop sign (inferior orbital wall fracture). Reference article, Radiopaedia.org.

https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-84923

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department after falling on his outstretched arm during a basketball game. An X-ray of the shoulder is performed and is shown below. What type of shoulder dislocation is most likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation

The x-ray shows Anterior dislocation of the shoulder

  • The lateral scapula or shoulder Y view is part of the standard shoulder X-ray series and is commonly used to assess shoulder dislocations. It can be technically challenging, especially in patients with pain.
  • A practical method used by radiographers involves aligning the medial border of the scapula with the anterior acromion to achieve superimposition of the scapular borders, indicating a proper lateral view-though this alignment may not always be perfect.
  • In this view, displacement of the humeral head from the glenoid helps determine dislocation type. If the humeral head lies anterior to the glenoid, it indicates an anterior shoulder dislocation

Explanation of Other Options:

Posterior Dislocation (Option A):

  • Mechanism: Seizures, electric shock, or trauma with internal rotation.
  • X-ray findings:
    • AP View: "Light bulb sign"- humeral head appears rounded (internally rotated).
    • Rim sign - widened glenohumeral space (>6 mm).
    • Absence of overlap between humeral head and glenoid.
    • Axillary view: The humeral head lies posterior to the glenoid (best seen here).

Inferior Dislocation (Option B):

  • Mechanism: Hyperabduction force.
  • Presentation: The arm is held above the head, unable to lower it.
  • X-ray findings:
    • The humeral head is dislocated inferiorly, below the glenoid.
    • The shaft of the humerus may point vertically.

Superior Dislocation (Option D):

  • Usually due to massive rotator cuff tears or trauma.
  • X-ray findings:
    • Humeral heads displaced superiorly may abut or override the acromion.
    • Associated with rotator cuff arthropathy or massive trauma.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man falls at home and presents with neck pain and limited neck mobility. He is neurologically intact. Identify the fractured bone
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The view shown is an Open-mouth odontoid X-ray view

  • The odontoid or 'peg' projection, also known as the open mouth AP projection (or radiograph), is an AP projection of C1 (atlas) and C2 (axis) with the patient's mouth open.
  • This view focuses primarily on the odontoid process of C2 and is useful in visualizing odontoid and Jefferson fractures. The odontoid fracture is seen as a horizontal radiolucent line running through the body of the odontoid process of the C2 vertebra.

Odontoid fractures are common in:

  • Elderly patients with falls
  • High-velocity trauma (e.g., car accidents)

Classified into:

  • Type I: Tip fracture (rare)
  • Type II: Through base (most common and unstable)
  • Type III: Extends into the C2 vertebral body

Explanation of Other Options:

Mandible (Option A):

  • Most commonly fractured facial bone in blunt trauma.
  • Fracture locations include:
    • Condyle
    • Angle
    • Body
    • Parasymphysis
    • Symphysis
  • Radiologic signs:
    • Step-off or discontinuity in the mandibular cortex.
    • Malalignment of dental arches.
    • Seen clearly on a panoramic X-ray (OPG) or CT scan.

Maxilla (Option B):

  • The upper jaw bone forms part of the midface and hard palate.
  • Maxillary fractures are classified as Le Fort I, II, and III.
  • Radiologically, look for:
    • Separation of pterygoid plates.
    • Step deformities in the infraorbital rim.
    • Involvement of nasal bones or orbits.

Alveolar Arch (Option D):

  • Part of the mandible or maxilla where teeth are embedded.
  • Fractures here are localized dental fractures, usually involving tooth sockets or the alveolar ridge.
  • May be part of a more extensive mandibular/maxillary fracture, but not the main bone in this case.

questions.text: Identify the type of fractures shown in the image below
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Open-book pelvic injuries are most often the result of high-energy trauma and anteroposterior compression injury and are associated with significant morbidity and mortality due to associated vascular injuries.
  • Open-book pelvic injuries result from an anteroposterior compression injury to the pelvis and result in a combination of ligamentous rupture and/or fractures to both the anterior and posterior arches:
  • anterior arch: pubic diastasis (+/- sacro tuberous/sacrospinous ligamentous disruption) and/or pubic rami fractures
  • posterior arch: sacroiliac joint widening or diastasis; posterior ilium fractures; sacral ala fractures.

Imaging features:

  • Widened pubic symphysis (>2.5 cm).
  • Possible sacroiliac joint widening.
  • The pelvis appears "opened like a book" on AP pelvic X-ray.

Explanation of Other Options:

Closed Book Fracture (Option A): This is a type of anterior-posterior compression (APC) pelvic injury, but less severe, with no significant widening of the pubic symphysis, minimal pelvic separation, a lower risk of major bleeding, and typically managed conservatively.

Linear Fracture (Option C): This refers to a non-displaced, straight-line fracture commonly seen in the skull or ribs and is not a term typically used to describe pelvic injuries.

questions.text: Identify the type of fracture shown below
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Neck of femur fractures (NOF), a.k.a. femoral neck fractures, are common injuries sustained by older patients who are both more likely to have unsteadiness of gait and reduced bone mineral density, predisposing to fracture.
  • Elderly osteoporotic women are at greatest risk. Since disruption of blood supply to the femoral head is dependent on the type of fracture and causes significant morbidity, the diagnosis and classification of these fractures are important. There are three types:
    • Subcapital: femoral head/neck junction
    • transcervical: midportion of femoral neck
    • basis cervical: base of femoral neck

Sub-capital and transcervical fractures are considered intracapsular fractures.
